Award.AwardTitle: South Asian Summer Monsoon Rainfall: Origin of Multidecadal Variability/Trends and Investigation of Seasonal Predictability
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Indo-Gangetic Plain is home to a billion people and is the agricultural heartland of South Asia. Rapid population and economic growth have led to significant land-use land-cover change, aerosol loadings, and greenhouse gas emissions. Regional hydroclimate exhibits substantial - at times, precarious - multidecadal trends: For example, summer rainfall over the Gangetic Plain has declined by 10-15% since the 1950s. The seasonal rainfall is moreover seldom predicted accurately; prediction skill has remained modest and stagnant despite advances in the representation of physical processes, numerical model resolution, and data assimilation.

This project has the following goals:(A) To investigate if the steep decline in post-1950s rainfall is from anthropogenic effects, multidecadal natural variability, or both. By revealing the nature of interference between secular change and natural variability, this attribution analysis will help estimate the likelihood of even steeper rainfall decline or some reprieve from drying in future decades. The modeling analysis will uncover the mechanisms through which multidecadal ocean variability influences the South Asian monsoon rainfall. (B) To determine the potential predictability of seasonal summer rainfall over South Asia from a discerning spatiotemporal analysis of 20th-21st century SST and rainfall observations, and rainfall reconstruction from contemporaneous and SST-leading rainfall regressions in an independent period - yielding a quantitative assessment of the SST-based predictability of monsoon rainfall at various seasonal leads. Intercomparison of the key SST-monsoon rainfall links in nature and historical simulations will advance the modeling of monsoon hydroclimate variability in two coupled climate models, viz. the Community Earth System Model(CESM) and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Geophysical Fluid Dynamics Lab (NOAA GFDL) model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Indo-Gangetic Plain is home to a billion people and is the agricultural heartland of South Asia. Rapid population and economic growth have led to increased demands on water resources; water is scarce but for summer -- the rainy season. Compounding water scarcity is the generally poor prediction of the summer monsoon rainfall distribution and the subpar management of surplus water when available. 

The project has developed a new strategy for the prediction of summer monsoon rainfall distribution over South Asia. It uses the global sea surface temperature (SST) distribution in antecedent seasons and historical rainfall data to develop the building blocks of monsoon prediction. The prediction system comprehensively mines the spatiotemporal space for all the SST-monsoon rainfall links, scoping out the full influence of SST on monsoon rainfall -- a first. The mining paves the way for skillful monsoon rainfall predictions, as assessed from the hindcast predictions in a 10-year long period completely independent of the statistical training period. A preliminary assessment indicates that the statistical prediction skill over the Indo-Gangetic Plain surpasses the prediction skill of current dynamical models. 

The project has addressed a seminal question in South Asian monsoon science -- one concerning the extent of predictability, i.e., the potential predictability of summer rainfall from the antecedent SSTs. The ENSO influence is well studied but a quantitative, integrated assessment of the influence of the full spectrum of antecedent SST variations was hitherto unavailable. The project outcome should reinvigorate moribund efforts on monsoon rainfall prediction. A promising beginning in this regard is the project's annual contribution, since the summer of 2016, to the India Meteorological Department's official summer monsoon forecast. 

The value of timely and reliable rainfall monsoon forecasts cannot be overstated for the agricultural economies of the region. Seasonal forecasts have assumed great significance recently as South Asia has become a highly resource-stressed region: It is this backdrop and the aspirations of a billion-plus people that generate the shrill demand for more accurate seasonal predictions. By contributing to their improvement, the project has some resonance with Sir Francis Bacon’s remark that "Science discovery should be driven not just by the quest for intellectual enlightenment, but also for the relief of man’s estate."
